The class is called international business, but never really talks about business.  It would be better called international economics, the economics of trade, or international trade.  The entire course is about trade.  There is no mention of FDI, raising capital, entering new markets, international HR best practices, IFRS, nor any other business topics.

The instructor is engaging and knowledgeable about international trade.  The quizzes are very easy.  And the class was enjoyable, it just wasn't about international business.

I've given 4 stars because the course achieves what it states in the description. Learning about the history of trade agreements and the interconnected variables that have led to our present day situation was very interesting. However, I would have liked to have gone into more detail on how businesses are best able to develop valuable positions in their markets, strategies employed by companies who trade globally and which business models to use and when - depending on country specific factors as well as global factors. A good introduction to the topic but much more detail and tie in's with real business examples would have been even better.
A good grounding, though can be a little dry, and the test questions are quite obvious.

If you want to improve your knowledges about internacional business, that is a very good tool to help you achieve it!
Well-designed, easy to understand, it is very useful to get ideas of globalization and present world of business.
